clauses.question: 1. What process should the Government use to set a new emissions reduction target in legislation?
clauses.answer: The Government sets a 2050 target in legislation now
clauses.notes:
If the Government can set the target earlier to say even 2040 (still 20+ years), the better. Naturally having it progressively staged is
 important to give businesses and individuals time to modify their behaviour including purchases in a planned manner.

clauses.question: 2. If the Government sets a 2050 target now, which is the best target for New Zealand?
clauses.answer: Net Zero Emissions - Net zero emissions across all greenhouse gases by 2050

clauses.question: 3. How should New Zealand meet its targets?
clauses.answer: Domestic emissions reductions only (including from new forest planting)
clauses.notes:
Overseas credits have proven to be miss leading as we are just offsetting our own emissions to other countries. All countries need to
 move to net zero emissions not just some. In addition when NZ did previously allow off shore carbon credits, there where scams

clauses.question: 4. Should the Zero Carbon Bill allow the 2050 target to be revised if circumstances change?
clauses.notes: The only exception would be pulling the target forward in time not pushing it back

clauses.question: 5. The Government proposes that three emissions budgets of five years each (i.e. covering the next 15 years) be in place at any given time. Do you agree with this proposal?
clauses.notes: It should be planned and signaled to everyone how NZ plans to get to Zero emissions. Being up front allows consumers to plan.

clauses.question: 6. Should the Government be able to alter the last emissions budget (i.e. furthest into the future)?
clauses.answer: No - emissions budgets should not be able to be changed
clauses.notes:
As mentioned above only if the targets can be bought forward (not delayed). If exceptions are allowed then some Governments may
 choose to use the out clause which in the future will end up cost future generations more to deal with the financial costs of climate

 change eg sea level rise and the cost to move whole communities

clauses.question: 7. Should the Government have the ability to review and adjust the second emissions budget within a specific range under exceptional circumstances? See p36 Our Climate Your Say
9. Should the Zero Carbon Bill require Governments to set out plans within a certain timeframe to achieve the emissions budgets?
10. What are the most important issues for the Government to consider in setting plans to meet budgets? For example, who do we need to work with, what else needs to be considered?
clauses.notes:
Encourage and help accelerated the uptake of EVs Encourage and help accelerate new large and small scale Wind, Hydro and Solar

electricity generation (not geothermal as it emits carbon, more than Huntly at the moment)

clauses.question: 11. The Government has proposed that the Climate Change Commission advises on and monitors New Zealand's progress towards its goals. Do you agree with these functions? See p42 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes:
As long as the Climate Change Commission can act impartially of Governaments and not be bought or influenced negatively by large
business

clauses.question: 12. What role do you think the Climate Change Commission should have in relation to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS)?
clauses.answer: Makes decisions itself in respect of the number of units available in the NZ ETS

clauses.question: 13. The Government has proposed that Climate Change Commissioners need to have a range of essential and desirable expertise. Do you agree with the proposed expertise? See p45 Our Climate Your Say
